I did not see any issues, when building locally. So I go ahead an merge.
Did not see any issues doing a local build. So going ahead and merge.

@wuh3 Great PR, thanks for your contribution!

I took the freedom to refactor that a bit. This PR is superseded by commit https://github.com/apache/causeway/commit/536317edbf1bd99119b68a294687aca53f9b765f.
Hello Andy, it's my honor that this PR inspired you. Great fix!
@wuh3 It did inspire me indeed! Though I perhaps should have merged your PR and refactored it from there. I instead took a shortcut. Sorry for that.

No worries! Your newly added helper class is very handy in my opinions. I may use it to further fix some other flaky tests. You may consider merging them first and refractor from there in the future, haha!

Hi @wuh3, I'm afraid, I'm not going to merge this one: Those `approval tests` currently in place, do have more value to us, than simple `assertTrue` tests.

For a brief intro see https://github.com/approvals/ApprovalTests.Java#what-can-it-be-used-for

Though we could normalize the XML sources before passing them to the approval tests, that would work.

Hello Andi,

I understand. Do you have any suggestions for a better fix?
As I said, normalize the XML sources, before passing them to the approval tests, would work.
I believe for the entire framework we in total have 5 approval tests. So I guess its fine, if there's no "fix" for these in particular.
Sounds good. I'll try me best. Thanks for the info!

Closing after a month of inactivity.

There is a dependency clash with

- `jakarta.activation`
- `jakarta.activation-api`

Both provide the `javax.activation.DataSource`.

Excluding `jakarta.activation` from `spring-boot-starter-mail` in `causeway-core-runtimeservices` helps resolve that:

```xml
<dependency>
    <groupId>org.springframework.boot</groupId>
    <artifactId>spring-boot-starter-mail</artifactId>
    <exclusions>
        <exclusion>
            <groupId>org.springframework.boot</groupId>
            <artifactId>spring-boot-starter-logging</artifactId>
        </exclusion>
        <exclusion>
           <groupId>com.sun.activation</groupId>
           <artifactId>jakarta.activation</artifactId>
        </exclusion>
    </exclusions>
</dependency>
```

`javax.activation.DataSource` is used to reference a mail attachment in our `EmailService` API. I just want to note that we have a similar `org.apache.causeway.commons.io.DataSource` that could be used instead (or in addition to not break backwards compatibility). 

That said, I'm not suggesting to do that, just stating that there is an option.

I guess this proposed filter is correct for entities and viewmodels, but not for values, which should be allowed to be `null`. I don't know if this method is ever called for values. (We have bookmark support for values now.)

If in doubt, the filter should let `ManagedObject`(s) of type VALUE pass, even if EMPTY.

Thanks for those suggestions, Andi - I'll refactor that way.  To answer your question, no - this method should never be called for a value, only for entities and view models.

This is an aside, but since you mentioned it: was does a bookmark for a value look like, eg a string "hello world" ?

> what does a bookmark for a value look like, eg a string "hello world" ?

Each value-type has its ValueTypeSemantics, which defines how to stringify and de-stringify a value. The stringified value is then made URL-SAFE by encoding it as base64 to create the id part of the bookmark.

An empty id part then corresponds to a NULL value.
